div.p: The default version of Erlang provided by your package manager should allow your RabbitMQ server to run, and will normally be sufficient. In all cases the minimum version required is at least R12B-3. Some functionality provided by erlang requires more recent versions.
In general use the latest available non-alpha version of Erlang unless you have a *really* good reason.

div.p: If using clustered nodes, all nodes should use the same version of Erlang.
Download Erlang or check on a specific version at http://www.erlang.org.

Check supported platforms.
Using a newer version of Erlang than the distribution repository provides
RedHat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) 5 and derived distributions (e.g. CentOS 5):
Due to
the EPEL package update policy, EPEL 5 contains Erlang version R12B-5, which rabbitmq-server still supports.
For better performance, and for certain non-core features (SSL support, HTTP-based plugins), use the most recent stable version of Erlang. The owner of the EPEL erlang package provides a package repository: (as root) wget -O /etc/yum.repos.d/epel-erlang.repo http://repos.fedorapeople.org/repos/peter/erlang/epel-erlang.repo. Invoking yum install erlang will then install or update Erlang.
Update the distribution
If you need newer features of Erlang than the package manager for your Linux distribution provides, it may be best to update your distribution.
Building Erlang from source
If you should need to build Erlang from source, you will need openssl installed on your system.
Be aware that if building Erlang from source, the package manager can't know whether the dependency is already available. So, for example, if you install an rpm package, you will get a dependency error. Mixing source builds with packages should be avoided.
